reviewText:
Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet is a 2D side-scrolling action/adventure Metroidvania game with puzzle elements. Basically you fly around in a small flying saucer and solve small puzzles while fighting off enemies and gigantic bosses. As you travel through the shadow planet you will get new abilities that allow you to backtrack to previous areas to open new areas like any Metroidvania type game, though most of the collectibles you find by backtracking are concept art pieces and short movie clips.

The art style and music create a very nice atmosphere, and the controls are fairly smooth. Most of the special abilities you get are very creative and fun to use, my favorite being the buzzsaw. There's not a lot of tutorials or hints, but there's an objective marker and you get an info tool you can point at things to find out how to interact with them.

All-in-all it was a very good game in my opinion and it's only about 8 hours to play through the entire game and find all of the collectibles. I recommend picking it up sometime.

reviewText:
Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet is notorious for two reasons. First and most obvious is absolutely glorious visual style by Michel Gagné; it’s dark, macabre, slightly frightening, but at the same time truly beautiful and not repulsing even by a tiny fraction despite all of the picturing of those tentacles and insect-like creatures. Second prominent feature is the protagonist. You see, despite all the variety of settings and worlds and stories a hero in metroidvania usually is a human, or at least some humanoid. But here you play as small flying saucer; so technically there’s still some humanoid inside. Obviously it impacts gameplay turning it into twin-stick shooter and omitting platforming with all it’s precision jumping and running. What it has instead is all different kinds of guns and devices that our UFO can use. Among them there are not only assorted lasers and blasters, but also a buzz-saw, a grappling claw, protective shield and so much more. So you fly around, shoot stuff and sometimes solve some puzzles. They’re neither challenging nor time consuming, but their presence is enough to transform what could be a blazing gun carnage into an exploration of beautiful yet twisted and insane world.
Speaking of which, there may be not a lot of variety on the first sight, but there surely is distinct difference on what kind of thrill you can expect from different game zones. There’s soothing calm of ice zone disturbed only by pesky and ubiquitous enemies; there’s tension of mandatory underwater level; and then there’s those enigmatic factory and all those different yet very familiar regions of the Shadow Planet. It’s not just bland similarity, but rather a true sense of interconnectivity that is the result of this distinct visual style of minimalistic mix of black shadows and pure-color backgrounds. This world doesn’t look or feel artificial, it’s as natural as a background for digital entertainment can get. It’s complete and interconnected; it feels solid, ready to be explored by a curious traveler, who’s on a mission to restore it, rather than just tear it apart.
And because of its small size and simple story the game forms an intimate bond with the player.  It’s not a feeling of attachment but rather a sense of lasting mutual sympathy. If anything,  Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet in a short few hours that you need to finish it accomplishes the task of teaching you a handful of interesting tricks while giving just enough time and space to toy with them to your amusement. Facing new challenge most of the time you either will know the solution right out or will figure it out faster than frustration kicks in. And that is not something easy to do, when an average gamer has an attention span shorter than one of a goldfish. Not that the game is a cakewalk from start to finish; there are bosses, you see. And they have all their bossy stuff: attack patterns, heavy attacks and weak points, that you’ll have to figure out to exploit them. So you’ll maybe even fail a few times while dealing with them.
Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet makes you feel invested without caring to present itself believable or even needing that for that matter. It’s a fiction that works on sheer kinetics and aesthetics; it doesn’t tell a story, it makes you perform it. The game simply unfolds with elegance and simplicity of a pop-up book and gives you the keys to the entrance.

reviewText:
A really fun game to pick up for a few bucks. At first it looks like it's going to be a mediocre shmup since you start with a pea shooter. However, it's actually more of a puzzle game than an action game. The early enemies are worth just breezing past. The game gets better as you add more and more tools. Some of the areas are quite clever in how they use their mechanics: shooting, bouncing laser beams, changing the screen orientation, picking up things, using a gravity beam, and cutting through rocks.

There are a few misses here though. The main one for me is the useless Metroidvania setup. The game will nicely mark the map in places where you need a specific tool to pass, but there's no way to fast travel there. So, if you actually follow up on the locked gates, you'll spend a lot of time backtracking only to get some pretty useless rewards: art/story unlocks and wimpy unneeded ship upgrades. Unless you're a completionist, don't worry too much about backtracking.

The story here is as simple as can be: Alien type B has invaded your Alien type A world. You need to destroy Alien type B to save Alien type A. There's no need for a more complex story in this kind of game, so I think that part of it was fine.

The graphics are nothing spectacular, but it does have a nice enough art style. It's generally pretty clear what everything is doing and the background and foreground don't mix together.

I've been playing a lot of indie titles for the last month, and seeing another shmup/puzzler didn't give me much faith, but I did enjoy the game in the four hours it took me to finish it.

reviewText:
ITSP is a very concise game. It might not be long, but it's always moving; you're always getting new equipment and doing new things. You're always solving puzzles that are mechanically different from the last. It is nearly devoid of filler unless you actually want to get all of the concept art unlocks, and this is a path that I prefer developers take. I want short games that don't endlessly repeat over long ones that feel like a chore.

The puzzles aren't the most difficult out there, but they're imaginative and are very appealing in visuals/effects. The entire game, in fact, is one of the most visually appealing games I've ever played. The world itself is alive and squirming around you. The animation and kinematics are extremely smooth. The camera fluidly zooms in and out to frame the environment around you; for boss battles this means you are a very tiny ship in front of a monster taking up half of your screen. Areas have distinct color palettes with parallax backgrounds (also with animated squirmy things moving around in the distance), but the palettes are always limited in nature and most feature the distinct black silhouetted foreground that probably caught your eye to begin with.

I have a few dislikes about the game. The first is that it feels like it straddles the border between explicitly telling a story and leaving the story to the gameplay. It has these confusing cutscenes that don't really assemble into much of anything I care about. Honestly, I am fine if you just show me the planet/sun being corrupted by a dark force, allow me to infer that I need to stop it, and leave me be for the rest of the game; let the gameplay tell the story. This plot is not on the scale of Mass Effect or The Witcher where you'd need anything else explained in any other way.

Secondly, despite the quasi-storytelling, it doesn't properly build up to an ending; there is nearly nothing to suggest that you're nearing your ultimate goal of cleansing the planet and no real signifier that the last boss is... well, the last boss. Yes, it's really big, but so are the other bosses, it doesn't strike you as particularly end-guy'ish, so you beat it, pat yourself on the back, and then realize the game is over. reviewText:
Finally, another Metroidvania game for the PC. There just aren't enough of these games around for PC. For those who don't know what Metroidvania means; it means that you're exploring a maze-like world with multiple paths, but instead of it being totally open, you have to start at one place, gather a weapon/ability and move to the other path, and so forth.

The graphics are 2D, clean and sharp and have, for a shadow planet, lots of personality. The sounds don't stand out and they certainly didn't wow me, but they got the job done.

Lengthwise it's about 4 hours long. There are some upgrades available for your ship, and they don't have to be collected to finish the game so there's a bit of extra exploration, but it isn't much. There is co-op to be found in this game, but I haven't tried it. It might add to the replayability. ITWS is a fun game, and it should be played, especially if you're a fan of the genre or if you've never played it at all.

reviewText:
A poor man's Aquaria on a prince's budget.

It's jarring to play such a beautifully made game, in my absolute favorite genre, and everything around me tells tells me it's wonderful... but for some reason it sucks.

The game is too forgiving from moment to moment, so much so that this scary planet actually tries to feed you health right within sight of your weird magical filling stations. Then you get locked into a boss fight with a single trial-and-error solution. If this is an homage to Metroid, it's an homage to the wrong part of Metroid.

The game is full of what seem like puzzles but aren't, and what seems like exploration but isn't. Nice touches squandered on room-by-room level design, and a scanner device that always tells you exactly what to do. A nice music system which is used for only one thing, and good sound marred by the constant whirr of your saucer engine.

None of these problems are absolutely damning, but together they sink what should have been a phenomenal game.

reviewText:
A Paladin's Steam Review: Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet. An Enjoyable Metroidvania That Made Me Feel Clever.Genre: 2D Metroidvania Exploration/Puzzle Game.
Developed & Published by: Shadow Planet Productions & Microsoft Studios
Platform: Windows, Mac and Linux
Business Model: Base Game only.
Copy Purchased by Myself Preamble
Fly around in your own “little” flying saucer picking up weapons or tools, figuring out puzzles and enjoying artistic backgrounds. The lack of gravity means you get a wide degree of movement though the levels themselves with limit where you can go. Gliding around in this flying saucer was definitely a different experience from the norm.

Overall Gameplay Thoughts
That being said, exploration and puzzle solving is the main focus of this game. Combat is straightforward with your weapons being easy to aim and land on enemies. That being said, you'll need to keep in mind that neither of you can handle more than a few shots, exempting bosses. So, it’s in your best interest to dodge the shots coming your way. The saucer can only heal from save checkpoints and rare health pickups, so avoid taking damage whenever possible. While enemies do re-spawn when they’re off-screen, they can be bypassed if you're simply passing through the area. Most of your time will be spent focusing on exploring this crazy planet you've landed on. Thanks to the pacing of the game and upgrades you can find, said exploration remains enjoyable the entire time.

What I really liked about this title is that I felt clever when I made progress. Boss fights aren't big slug fests where you outlast your enemies but outthink them. You just need to use the tools and weapons you find along the way. If you’re having a frustrating time with a certain situation you find yourself in, you probably need to think your way out of it differently. Use the scanning tool. It will help you out a lot if you get stuck. The only part of this game that can get overly frustrating is the ice level, where you have to place ice crystals in the right places to get a beam of light to where you need it. The pick-up tool is...quirky and sometimes won't place the crystals correctly.

Story
You follow the adventure of an alien who has gone to...well...an insanely twisted up shadowy planet to stop an invading force from destroying their planet. At least, that’s what I got out of the story. Most of the story is shown via pictures and cutscenes with no text or voice over to really clue you in to what’s going on. As the cutscenes are short, they only give you a basic idea of what’s going on. So, there’s not much to say about the story.

PC Settings and Port Report
ITSP makes it way from Xbox to the PC platform in good form. Custom resolutions, fullscreen, texture and shader quality sliders (on/off choices) as well as depth of field and anti-aliasing up to 8x are here. It’s more than I’d expect from a 2D game but I’m definitely not complaining. The game runs exceptionally well and I never ran into bugs or crashes during my time with it. Keyboard bindings are present but you’ll have a better time with a controller as the movement simply feels more natural with an analogue stick. I didn't try out any of the multiplayer, I just wasn't all that interested in it.

Final Thoughts
It felt like this title mostly got ignored, which is a shame because there’s a really solid game here. Sure, the laser puzzles are finicky and the combat depth is shallow. But the presentation is solid, the pacing is great and the atmosphere is really nice. Add in some fun exploration and clever boss fights to make for a great title.

Released nearly three years ago, I only recently picked up and played Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet. I left the experience rather satisfied. Which is rare, as this genre is so often plagued with some sort of pacing or mechanical issues that get in the way of having a fun time. I recommend picking Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet up if you're in the market for this type of game.

reviewText: Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet follows the Metroidvania formula well with a diverse selection of weapons, all of which suit the theme and present new options both for exploration and for combat. The world is almost entirely open and gates that can only be unlocked with new weapons pop up from the beginning. The map clearly shows what has been explored and what hasn't and can even note the weapon needed for a particular gate. It's all here, save the fun. There's just too much frustration to allow fun to flourish. Enemies respawn at surprising rates which would be fine if it was any fun to shoot them. Past the first time realizing that a new weapon would be better used on this enemy or that, fighting is a chore. The often narrow, obstacle-fulled corridors would be more at home in a puzzle-platformer which Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet very nearly is, and would be better for being. The two co-op modes - a feature that should be an absolute boon for such a short game - doesn't help with that either. They both emphasize the worst elements of the game by adding more combat and forcing the player to cart something around for the entire mode, a mechanic that only serves to point out how finicky the grabber arm is. Both modes also feature a timed element and remove all the enjoyable exploration and permanent advancement that made the main campaign so close to being something great in the first place. And there is something great hiding in Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet. Sadly, it's just too buried under layers and layers of poor execution to really shine.

reviewText:
Interesting little game. As the screenshots show, this game has a sort of cartoony dark sci-fi horror theme going, which is easily its best point. But the world design and the myriad of puzzles and enemies are great as well. Especially boss fights are well rounded out: not too easy nor too hard, making use of a mechanic you've learned previously and usually rewarding you with a new toy to play with.

The controls took some getting used to (especially guiding rockets), and I found swapping the controller for a keyboard and mouse to make things MUCH easier (this is probably me, though).

As for the story: take it for good or for bad, but there is no dialogue. At all. No cutscene text, no voice-overs, no tutorials (in the literal sense...level design is set to make you acquainted with new weapons), no nothing.  So you can only take a guess at things like why you're there or even what the weapons are called, but it doesn't distract much. This is a game that should be played...not watched or read.

'metroidvania' is the typical term for this sort of game (only one huge-♥♥♥ level but most parts are locked until you have a certain item), but I'm not sure I want to classify it as such. The reason is that it felt pretty linear. I rarely backtracked or explored anything outside where I was pointed out to go, and the only time I felt lost was in the part where the map rotated (you'll know when you get there). Oh, and you're flying a spaceship. That's a rather unusual (if not unique) approach for this kind of game.

But all in all, it's certainly a game worth playing. Not very long, but it shouldn't be any longer: as it is, it's packed with all the good stuff. :-)

In score, I'd say 7,5 or 8 on 10. But since it's personal, it doesn't say much on what YOU may think it's worth...

We exploded aliens, solved puzzles, and, in generally, kicked ♥♥♥. What more is there to say? Let’s get into the review.

I – Story [6/10]

Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet is a  2-D action/adventure from Shadow Planet Productions. The story is simple: you (an alien) are tasked with exploring an incredibly hostile planet; making your way steadily to the center in the hopes that you can save your home world by destroying an alien infestation at it’s source. Like I said, simple. But, it was well done all the same.

II – UI [8/10]

The user interface in ITSP is intuitive and easy to master. HUD is almost non-existent, forcing you to really on visuals to assess your level of health. There is no reticle for aiming (which I wasn’t the biggest fan of, but whatever). The map was very user friendly, but can become cumbersome as there is no mini-map on screen. When you receive a new objective, a directional bubble points you in the right direction and off you go.

III – Gameplay [10/10]

There are three modes of play in ITSP. Firstly, there was the campaign. As I explained above, the story line is simple and there are no real side quests to speak of. You make your journey deeper and deeper into the hostile planet until you have accomplished your ultimate goal.

One of my favorite aspects of the game was the research tool that your space craft is equipped with. You will use this tool the entire game to figure out how things work and to assist you in solving various puzzles. You point it at what needs scanning, scan it, and then pick the right tool for the job. I personally thought that this was a novel way of learning as you go and getting through the game.

Combat is simple; just point and shoot (or saw, in a lot of cases). Each enemy has a certain weapon that is best against it, though you don’t strictly have to use that one weapon if you don’t want to. Why blow something up with a rocket when you can melt it with a laser beam or cut it in half with a gigantic saw blade? My thoughts exactly.

The second game mode is called “Lantern Run”. While all the game modes are co-op, this one was definitely designed to be played co-op rather than alone. In this mode of play the player(s) have to drag a lantern (or multiple lanterns) as far into a cavern as they can go. All the while they are being chased by a huge alien monster. Every so far into the cavern, the player(s) must stop in an arena and fight respawning enemies until the big one catches up and breaks through the next wall for you. If all of the lanterns break, it’s game over.

The third game mode is called “Shadow Hunters”. Again, this is another one that was designed for co-op. The player(s) must drag a bomb through a cavern that is teeming with enemies. The bomb has a timer that is always counting down, though it can be recharged at bomb recharge stations. If the bomb takes damage, the timer goes down faster. Every so far down the cavern, the player(s) will again be stopping in caverns to fight both regular enemies and boss enemies (hence the bomb you’re carrying).

While all the modes of play were pretty fun, I particularly enjoyed the campaign best. Though, I didn’t have the chance to get much co-op time in.

IV – Content [6/10]

For as big of an in-game map as ITSP has, I was a bit disappointed by the amount of content. There are several tools that you’ll zoom around the planet collecting, but only one is upgradeable. In addition to this, while your hull armor is also upgradeable, there is no way to change what your craft looks like (even though other space crafts are selectable in the Shadow Hunters game mode).

There were a lot of different enemy types though, although a seemed to be the same enemy with a new theme for each biome of the planet. The boss battles were all pretty fun, blending combat and puzzle solving into a chaotic good time.

V – Visuals [10/10]

The visuals of Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet were splendid. It had a creepy, Tim Burton-esque feel and was almost endearing in a way. While the enemies were fascinating enough, it was the environments of the planet that were truly breathtaking and made exploring the hostile underground a real treat.

VI – Audio [10/10]

The music of ITSP was fantastic and always seem to kick in right when it would boost the immersion the most. The ambiance throughout the game was great and all the sound effects fit in to the game world perfectly.

VII – Overall [8.3/10]

Overall, Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet is a genuinely fun game and is easily worth the full price tag. If you can get it on sale, great, if not, you won’t be disappointed anyway.

Really love this game. It's Super Metroid in a flying saucer with physics puzzles and beatiful 2D visuals somewhere in between Limbo, World of Goo, and Tim Burton. Every collectible is fun to acquire, every weapon/item is useful and fun to use, and the gating of areas is almost always tied to inventive use of your items and is never a glorified lock and key ala Metroid's weapon-specific doors. In order to progress from area to area you will do things like ride currents through twisty underwater tunnels, reflect laser beams off of ice crystals, and drill passageways through rock walls. The boss fights are exciting and well designed, requiring you to make interesting uses of the tools you have acquired (similar to Zelda boss fights except more intricate). Music is wonderful, usually just ambient themes to set the mood of each region, with occasional uptempo moments reminscent of the most exciting parts of older Danny Elfman movie scores.

Control is very good with the mouse and keyboard, though if you have a twin analogue stick controller, I suspect the game will play even better this way. You move your ship in 8 directions with the keyboard, and aim your weapons/items in 360 degrees with the mouse. You switch between items with a radial menu brought up by bolding the right mouse button.

Combat is a relatively small part of the game, but well done. Enemies are varied and require different tactics to take down. Most enemies are perticularly vulnerable to a specific weapon, but all of them can be tackled in more than one way. There is considerable overlap between enemies/items/environmental elements, and oftentimes you will solve puzzles by manipulating enemies. There are many things which can kill you, but very few cheap deaths. There are ample checkpoints throughout the game so you are never set too far back when you die.

Exploration is a healthy balance of backtracking and unlocking new areas. There are optional side paths to explore which lead to upgrades and other collectibles. Each area has a distinct look, which makes it easier to keep track of where you are going. There is an auto-map feature which fills in as you explore new areas, and a red blinking objective is marked on the map at all times, indicating where you should go next in order to progress.

Your ship is equipped with a scanner ala metroid prime, which can be used to get information on enemies' weaknesses, as well as indicating which item is needed to break through obstacles or activate certain objects. The great thing about this is that once you scan an obstacle, your map will be updated with an icon indicating which item is needed to proceed. This way you can easily find your way back to the same spot when you have the item you need. By the time you acquire each new item, you will already have marked several places on the map where it is needed, which means you'll immediately have a list of places to return to and try out your new items.

Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet is a decent side scrolling adventure. You play the role of a trapped flying saucer looking for a way off a dark and twisted planet. You end up having to find multiple puzzles pieces and ship upgrades to move through the different areas. There are several boss battles that require certain weapon strategies along with several cool physics based puzzles. It's short, slightly boring, but still enjoyable.

ITSP feels sort of like a Metroid-lite twin-stick space shooter that features a blend of combat, puzzles, and exploration. While the game does combat quite nicely for the most part, it struggles in the other two areas. Puzzles are usually interesting yet don't provide much of a challenge. And despite the map being so massive, there's a lot of backtracking and perhaps too much linearity over the course of the campaign.

In spite of these issues, ITSP is still a fun experience. Its best accomplishment is creating a wonderful world that oozes atmosphere through its eerie ambient sounds and a colorful animation style that's used to create some beautiful, creepy and varied environments. There's a good variety of ship upgrades, although switching between them on a gamepad can be clunky. The main campaign is pretty short but I felt that was much more preferable to dragging on for too long. And while the puzzle-solving isn't a strong point, the combat portions of the game are fun thanks to the simplified controls and bizarre enemies/bosses.

While far from perfect, ITSP is a solid enough game to warrant a discounted purchase. A flawed yet atmospheric and beautiful space shooter that features huge and diverse locations and some solid twin-stick combat.

We exploded aliens, solved puzzles, and, in generally, kicked ♥♥♥. What more is there to say? Let’s get into the review.

I – Story [6/10]

Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet is a  2-D action/adventure from Shadow Planet Productions. The story is simple: you (an alien) are tasked with exploring an incredibly hostile planet; making your way steadily to the center in the hopes that you can save your home world by destroying an alien infestation at it’s source. Like I said, simple. But, it was well done all the same.

II – UI [8/10]

The user interface in ITSP is intuitive and easy to master. HUD is almost non-existent, forcing you to really on visuals to assess your level of health. There is no reticle for aiming (which I wasn’t the biggest fan of, but whatever). The map was very user friendly, but can become cumbersome as there is no mini-map on screen. When you receive a new objective, a directional bubble points you in the right direction and off you go.

III – Gameplay [10/10]

There are three modes of play in ITSP. Firstly, there was the campaign. As I explained above, the story line is simple and there are no real side quests to speak of. You make your journey deeper and deeper into the hostile planet until you have accomplished your ultimate goal.

One of my favorite aspects of the game was the research tool that your space craft is equipped with. You will use this tool the entire game to figure out how things work and to assist you in solving various puzzles. You point it at what needs scanning, scan it, and then pick the right tool for the job. I personally thought that this was a novel way of learning as you go and getting through the game.

Combat is simple; just point and shoot (or saw, in a lot of cases). Each enemy has a certain weapon that is best against it, though you don’t strictly have to use that one weapon if you don’t want to. Why blow something up with a rocket when you can melt it with a laser beam or cut it in half with a gigantic saw blade? My thoughts exactly.

The second game mode is called “Lantern Run”. While all the game modes are co-op, this one was definitely designed to be played co-op rather than alone. In this mode of play the player(s) have to drag a lantern (or multiple lanterns) as far into a cavern as they can go. All the while they are being chased by a huge alien monster. Every so far into the cavern, the player(s) must stop in an arena and fight respawning enemies until the big one catches up and breaks through the next wall for you. If all of the lanterns break, it’s game over.

The third game mode is called “Shadow Hunters”. Again, this is another one that was designed for co-op. The player(s) must drag a bomb through a cavern that is teeming with enemies. The bomb has a timer that is always counting down, though it can be recharged at bomb recharge stations. If the bomb takes damage, the timer goes down faster. Every so far down the cavern, the player(s) will again be stopping in caverns to fight both regular enemies and boss enemies (hence the bomb you’re carrying).

While all the modes of play were pretty fun, I particularly enjoyed the campaign best. Though, I didn’t have the chance to get much co-op time in.

IV – Content [6/10]

For as big of an in-game map as ITSP has, I was a bit disappointed by the amount of content. There are several tools that you’ll zoom around the planet collecting, but only one is upgradeable. In addition to this, while your hull armor is also upgradeable, there is no way to change what your craft looks like (even though other space crafts are selectable in the Shadow Hunters game mode).

There were a lot of different enemy types though, although a seemed to be the same enemy with a new theme for each biome of the planet. The boss battles were all pretty fun, blending combat and puzzle solving into a chaotic good time.

V – Visuals [10/10]

The visuals of Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet were splendid. It had a creepy, Tim Burton-esque feel and was almost endearing in a way. While the enemies were fascinating enough, it was the environments of the planet that were truly breathtaking and made exploring the hostile underground a real treat.

VI – Audio [10/10]

The music of ITSP was fantastic and always seem to kick in right when it would boost the immersion the most. The ambiance throughout the game was great and all the sound effects fit in to the game world perfectly.

VII – Overall [8.3/10]

Overall, Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet is a genuinely fun game and is easily worth the full price tag. If you can get it on sale, great, if not, you won’t be disappointed anyway.

Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet is a terrific single player action adventure game. It combines all of the greatest elements from a metroid-vania style 2-D platformer with some really impressive physics and visuals.

Graphics: The game boasts a very impressive art-style throughout. The dark and ominous alien life-forms that you battle througout the game really exemplify this art style. As you explore the relatively large game-world, you will come across a series of diverse and unique landscapes. From ocean caverns to mechanical factories, the game provides a relatively aesthetic treat.

Gameplay: This game plays a lot like your typical metroid-vania game. It does mix it up quite a bit by throwing in a series of interesting physics puzzles. While I never really got caught up on these puzzles, they did break up the pace quite nicely. The combat in the game is very simple. It handles like a typical 2-D shooter, with a relatively sparse variety of weapons and enemies. Over-all, the combat rarely felt difficult or over-whelming (Especially the final boss). In terms of difficulty, you'll find that this game is a cake-walk.

Replayability: In the single-player aspect, I wouldn't really recommend it to people who are looking for a deep and lengthy game. The single-player story will last you approximately 5 hours to beat. While the game does encourage you to return to previous levels once you unlock more tools to unlock some concept art and movies, this content is very short-winded, and will probably only take most people an additional hour.

In addition to the relatively short single-player campaing, there are a few multiplayer game-modes. While I tried them out in single-player, these were clearly meant to be played with at least another player. Unfortuantely there aren't many players online, so you'll need to find other users that own the game (or gather your friends to play locally). I really can't say much about the multi-player due to the fact that I never really got into it, but it could provide for a significantly longer play-time if you have a few willing friends.

Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone looking for a unique metroid-vania game.

Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet is a 2D side-scrolling action/adventure Metroidvania game with puzzle elements. Basically you fly around in a small flying saucer and solve small puzzles while fighting off enemies and gigantic bosses. As you travel through the shadow planet you will get new abilities that allow you to backtrack to previous areas to open new areas like any Metroidvania type game, though most of the collectibles you find by backtracking are concept art pieces and short movie clips.

The art style and music create a very nice atmosphere, and the controls are fairly smooth. Most of the special abilities you get are very creative and fun to use, my favorite being the buzzsaw. There's not a lot of tutorials or hints, but there's an objective marker and you get an info tool you can point at things to find out how to interact with them.

All-in-all it was a very good game in my opinion and it's only about 8 hours to play through the entire game and find all of the collectibles. I recommend picking it up sometime when it's on sale.

Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet is a terrific single player action adventure game. It combines all of the greatest elements from a metroid-vania style 2-D platformer with some really impressive physics and visuals.

Graphics: The game boasts a very impressive art-style throughout. The dark and ominous alien life-forms that you battle througout the game really exemplify this art style. As you explore the relatively large game-world, you will come across a series of diverse and unique landscapes. From ocean caverns to mechanical factories, the game provides a relatively aesthetic treat.

Gameplay: This game plays a lot like your typical metroid-vania game. It does mix it up quite a bit by throwing in a series of interesting physics puzzles. While I never really got caught up on these puzzles, they did break up the pace quite nicely. The combat in the game is very simple. It handles like a typical 2-D shooter, with a relatively sparse variety of weapons and enemies. Over-all, the combat rarely felt difficult or over-whelming (Especially the final boss). In terms of difficulty, you'll find that this game is a cake-walk.

Replayability: In the single-player aspect, I wouldn't really recommend it to people who are looking for a deep and lengthy game. The single-player story will last you approximately 5 hours to beat. While the game does encourage you to return to previous levels once you unlock more tools to unlock some concept art and movies, this content is very short-winded, and will probably only take most people an additional hour.

In addition to the relatively short single-player campaing, there are a few multiplayer game-modes. While I tried them out in single-player, these were clearly meant to be played with at least another player. Unfortuantely there aren't many players online, so you'll need to find other users that own the game (or gather your friends to play locally). I really can't say much about the multi-player due to the fact that I never really got into it, but it could provide for a significantly longer play-time if you have a few willing friends.

Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone looking for a unique metroid-vania game.

Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet says ♥♥♥♥ that, you're a flying saucer, now fly around and shoot things. The overall length is noticbly short, especially for a Metroidvania, but it it's a solid experience the whole way through. reviewText: As a fan of exploration, discovery, and avatar empowerment in video games, ITSP has everything that I could hope for. Equal parts Metroid, Aquaria, Solar Jetman, and Limbo, the sheer atmosphere of the game begs you to play for just a little more, just to see what's next. I need to emphasize the bosses in this game, wherein half the challenge and fun is figuring out what to do. If you like puzzles, arcade shooting, Metroidvania-style exploration, and beautiful landscapes, get this game. Its one of the best I've played this year.
